bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 28, 1896

div1.p: Lazear writes that he is leaving for California, although he dreads the long journey.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 28, 1896
div1.p:
I have
finally concluded
not to go out to
Windsor but to
leave for California
tomorrow evening.
I have got my
work in such shape
that I can do this
all right.
I think I shall
go right through
reaching San Francisco
on Saturday.

I had expected
to go out to Windsor
today but I got a
note from Mr. Joe
Seth saying that
Aunt Kate was on
the Eastern shore but
would return tonight
and that she wanted
me to make myself at home.
However I concluded to go
out tomorrow to say good bye
to them. I am going on the
initial trip on the new Electric
Road to Windsor.

I received your letter of June 22
I don't know what to say about
the subscription to the Hopkins
Fund. On the whole I think
it just as well to subscribe
and I thank you very much
for putting the money at my
disposal, for I could not
have thought of subscribing without
your assistance.
I shall write to
you on the road
and as soon as
I reach San Francis-
co. I dread the
long ride in the
cars. Five days is
a frightfully long
stretch. I would
much rather cross
the ocean.

I packed all my
books and things and
I shall leave them in the store
room here at the hospital
until fall.

Baltimore is beginning to
look deserted. It has been
sultry and rainy.

You know the Houston's
address of course - 2232
Broadway.
